programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Core Kyoto
programme.sub-title: Versatile Oil: Smoothing the Way in Everyday Life
programme.desc: Kyoto dominated the oil market 1,000 years ago. Various oils fueled votive lamps, flavored food, preserved wood, and were used in pomade and cosmetics. Oil still plays a key role in the culture today.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Outside in Lost in Academia
programme.desc: Norwegian sociolinguist Goran Vaage investigates Japanese laughter, or warai. He analyzes how comedy is ingrained into communication in everyday life and plays a vital role in social connection.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Today's Close-Up
programme.sub-title: Unusual Boom in Property Market: What's Driving Housing Price Surge in Japan
programme.desc: For years, property prices and rents in Japan's urban areas barely changed. Then in 2023, the market exploded to life as investment money started pouring into new condos. In many cases, buyers are rapidly reselling for profit, a practice that's driving prices skyward and pushing house-hunters toward the used market or rentals. The result has been a sharp rise in prices there, too, leaving many renters in a precarious financial position. We look at what one municipal government in Tokyo is doing to counter the trend, and ask experts how residents can find an affordable place to live. Guests: Nagashima Osamu (Real estate consultant) Nozawa Chie (Professor, Meiji University)

programme.title: NEWSROOM TOKYO
programme.desc: NEWSROOM TOKYO dives deeper into the day's news with insight and analysis, from the perspective of Japan and the rest of Asia. We put a spotlight on what you need to know to understand the issues.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Training Dogs to Save Lives Around the World
programme.desc: Murase Hidehiro trains search-and-rescue dogs to save lives in disaster areas around the world. He talks about the importance of having dogs that are specifically able to respond to disasters in Asia.

programme.title: DOSUKOI Sumo Salon
programme.desc: This is a move that can be used either for defense or offense. We take a deep dive into how it works and how it's been employed throughout sumo history to trip up even fearsome opponents!

programme.title: The Beauty of Japanese Swords: Famous Masterpieces
programme.desc: This time, a famous swordsmith's blade that was cherished by the shoguns who ruled Edo-period Japan.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.sub-title: The Man with the Piercing Gaze
programme.desc: A man strikes a pose in an iconic woodblock print by the artist Sharaku. Who is the mysterious figure ... and what is he doing? And why did the artist want to commemorate the moment? *"The Actor Otani Oniji III as Edobei" (1794) by Toshusai Sharaku

programme.title: Hometown Stories
programme.sub-title: Chasing a Dream With a Horse
programme.desc: Nishino Masatoshi didn't know what he wanted to do with his life until he learned about horse logging. Now, he's chasing his dream in the forests of Hokkaido with the help of his trusty sidekick, Kap.

programme.title: Satoyama Kitchen Diary
programme.sub-title: Hot Days and Cool Nights Make Tasty Veggies
programme.desc: Hello, it's me, Tama! What do I do on hot summer days? I hide in the shade! This morning, Grandpa Makoto and Grandma Nobuko are shopping for summer veggies for today's feast. I hope they buy some for me, too!

programme.title: Japanology Plus
programme.desc: *First broadcast on November 6, 2025 Interest in sleep has been growing in Japan. From futuristic high-tech beds to advanced sleepwear, many new products are designed to improve sleep quality. We look at Japan's latest sleep trends.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Japan Railway Journal
programme.sub-title: On Track for a Carbon-Free Future
programme.desc: Across the country, Japan's railways are working towards a shared goal: carbon neutrality. See the efforts being made to shift away from diesel power and to improve energy efficiency overall.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Today's Close-Up
programme.sub-title: More Than Books: Libraries as Community Hubs
programme.desc: So-called "lively libraries" that promote new concepts, such as allowing people to chat, eat and drink are gaining popularity, resulting in a sharp increase in users in an era of declining population. Some facilities use books and magazines to promote intergenerational exchanges and resolve local issues. In addition, some local governments have focused on their libraries' ability to attract users by allowing people to use them for free as a key part of urban development. We visit a library in Gifu that has seen its visitor numbers increase tenfold. What is the potential for public spaces to evolve into places for everyone? Guests: Yoshinari Nobuo (Former General Producer, Minna no Mori Gifu Media Cosmos) Itoga Masaru (Professor Emeritus, Keio University)

programme.desc: In 2025, Otani Akira's book "The Night of Baba Yaga" won the UK's prestigious Dagger prize for crime fiction in translation - a first for a Japanese author. She talks about the inspiration behind her work.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Tradition and Innovation in Sake Brewing
programme.desc: 92-year-old sake brewer Noguchi Naohiko has made significant contributions to the sake industry over his seven-decade career. He talks about carrying on old traditions while innovating new ones.

programme.title: DOSUKOI Sumo Salon
programme.desc: We look at the penultimate 14th day of sumo tournaments, and dive into historical moments that prove this day can be as or more exciting than the final one, like an emotional brotherly title win!

programme.title: The Beauty of Japanese Swords: Famous Masterpieces
programme.desc: This time, a blade wielded by Miyamoto Musashi, the world's most famous swordsman: Musashi Masamune.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.sub-title: Reproduction of Nihonbashi: Morning Scene by Utagawa Hiroshige
programme.desc: Mornings begin early for fishmongers and vegetable peddlers at Nihonbashi Bridge, and here is a reason. They are not going to bow to the lord's procession. The bustling scene from everyday Edo life.

programme.title: BIZ STREAM
programme.desc: [On-Site Report: Shoring Up Short-Handed Kitchens] This episode features new services and cooking equipment designed to help restaurants in Japan overcome a deepening labor shortage.

programme.title: FRONTRUNNERS
programme.desc: Watanabe Hiroki is co-founder of an NGO in Bangladesh. It gives long-term support to underprivileged children on the street, proving that they can make a positive contribution to society.

programme.sub-title: On Track for a Carbon-Free Future
programme.desc: Across the country, Japan's railways are working towards a shared goal: carbon neutrality. See the efforts being made to shift away from diesel power and to improve energy efficiency overall.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Today's Close-Up
programme.sub-title: More Than Books: Libraries as Community Hubs
programme.desc: So-called "lively libraries" that promote new concepts, such as allowing people to chat, eat and drink are gaining popularity, resulting in a sharp increase in users in an era of declining population. Some facilities use books and magazines to promote intergenerational exchanges and resolve local issues. In addition, some local governments have focused on their libraries' ability to attract users by allowing people to use them for free as a key part of urban development. We visit a library in Gifu that has seen its visitor numbers increase tenfold. What is the potential for public spaces to evolve into places for everyone? Guests: Yoshinari Nobuo (Former General Producer, Minna no Mori Gifu Media Cosmos) Itoga Masaru (Professor Emeritus, Keio University)

programme.title: NEWSROOM TOKYO
programme.desc: NEWSROOM TOKYO dives deeper into the day's news with insight and analysis, from the perspective of Japan and the rest of Asia. We put a spotlight on what you need to know to understand the issues.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Picture Books for Children and Adults Alike
programme.desc: In 2024, Miyakoshi Akiko won a New York Times' Best Illustrated Children's Book Award. We see how she creates art, using charcoal and watercolors. And we discover the inspiration behind her work.

programme.title: IMPACTS: Climates Change the World
programme.sub-title: Endangered Journey: The Decline of Japan's Chum Salmon
programme.desc: Japanese chum salmon migrate over 20,000 kilometers in their return journey across the North Pacific. Global warming has caused an alarming decline in returning salmon and requires urgent action.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.desc: We observe "Red Fuji" and "Black Fuji," 2 dramatically different views of Japan's most famous mountain, captured by the artist Hokusai. What did Mount Fuji mean to the people of Edo? *"Southern Wind at Clear Dawn," "Rainstorm beneath the Summit" from the series "Thirty-six views of Mount Fuji" (1830-31) by Katsushika Hokusai

programme.title: Medical Frontiers
programme.sub-title: Exercise Is the Key to Surviving Cancer
programme.desc: A growing body of research shows that continuing to exercise after a cancer diagnosis can improve post-surgical recovery, reduce recurrence rates and even increase survival rates.

programme.title: Special program
programme.desc: A wide range of topics featuring Japanese culture and society are introduced.

programme.title: Time and Tide
programme.sub-title: YOKAI: Exploring Hidden Japanese Folklore â€“ KITSUNE
programme.desc: The fox, or KITSUNE also holds an identity as a supernatural creature commonly depicted at shrines, known for its ability to masquerade as humans to deceive them, or to provide divine messages.

programme.title: Magical Japanese
programme.desc: The Japanese language is rich in words and expressions influenced by nature, history and culture. This episode focuses on the many words born from the ancient board game, Go, that are now a part of everyday speech.

programme.title: MATSURI: The Heartbeat of Japan
programme.desc: Inami Shishimai is a type of lion dance performed in Toyama Prefecture. Here, the shishi symbolizes the harshness and bounty of the natural world, and the matsuri focuses on the importance of harmony between people and nature. Adults play the role of the enormous shishi while a child is the shishi-tori, whose job is to pacify the shishi with sacred objects. This event is also an opportunity for local families to wish for happy marriages and children, and the shishi dances in celebration.

programme.sub-title: New Farming for a Changing Climate
programme.desc: Climate change continues, and heat is affecting crops. Some Japanese farmers are adjusting to compensate, like a citrus farmer growing subtropical fruits and a farm that generates solar power.

programme.title: BOSAI: Science that Can Save Your Life
programme.desc: In September 2018, the Hokkaido Eastern Iburi Earthquake knocked out power of the entire region, affecting up to 2.95 million households. The tremor caused several power plants to shut down, disrupting the electrical frequency. This led to a chain reaction of other power plants to shut down. People's lives were greatly affected, as medical equipment failed and logistics systems were disrupted. What can we do to prevent such large-scale power outages? Find out what research institutes and local communities are doing to take steps against massive blackouts.

programme.title: DESIGN MUSEUM JAPAN
programme.desc: Aichi Prefecture / Kataoka Mami (Curator) Tokoname, a pottery town with over 900 years of history, creates products appropriate for the times. Kataoka finds the beauty that's present in functional objects.

programme.title: Somewhere Street
programme.desc: The history of Melaka, a city in Malaysia, dates back to the 15th century Melaka Sultanate, when it became a thriving maritime trade hub. During this period, Islam spread rapidly due to the influence of Arab trading partners. In the 16th century, the Portuguese sought control of Melaka to dominate its strategic trade routes. The city later came under Dutch rule in the 17th century, followed by British control in the 19th century. Despite these shifts in colonial rulers, Melaka continued to prosper as a significant port town.

programme.title: National Parks of Japan:Akan-Mashu
programme.desc: Akan-Mashu National Park is home to Lake Akan, Lake Kussharo, and Lake Mashu. It provides unique winter sights and the opportunity to experience the indigenous Ainu culture.

programme.title: Chatroom Japan
programme.sub-title: An Education Chance Opens the World
programme.desc: Maxine is a university student. She joined a school providing educational support and life advice to international students wanting to enter Japanese high school. This experience changed her life. What insights did she gain?

programme.title: IMPACTS: Climates Change the World
programme.sub-title: Endangered Journey: The Decline of Japan's Chum Salmon
programme.desc: Japanese chum salmon migrate over 20,000 kilometers in their return journey across the North Pacific. Global warming has caused an alarming decline in returning salmon and requires urgent action.

programme.title: DESIGN MUSEUM JAPAN
programme.desc: Aichi Prefecture / Kataoka Mami (Curator) Tokoname, a pottery town with over 900 years of history, creates products appropriate for the times. Kataoka finds the beauty that's present in functional objects.

programme.title: Where We Call Home
programme.desc: We revisit Pakistani Habib ur Rahman, a crafter of custom-made power wheelchairs in Kobayashi, Miyazaki Prefecture, and meet Edson Moreno, a Brazilian truck driver based in Iwata, Shizuoka Prefecture.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Time-lapse Japan
programme.desc: The Jomon period dates roughly from 13,000 to 300 BC. We examine various aspects of Jomon society, with footage from time-lapse creator Shimizu Daisuke. This time: Dogu.

programme.title: BOSAI: Science that Can Save Your Life
programme.desc: In September 2018, the Hokkaido Eastern Iburi Earthquake knocked out power of the entire region, affecting up to 2.95 million households. The tremor caused several power plants to shut down, disrupting the electrical frequency. This led to a chain reaction of other power plants to shut down. People's lives were greatly affected, as medical equipment failed and logistics systems were disrupted. What can we do to prevent such large-scale power outages? Find out what research institutes and local communities are doing to take steps against massive blackouts.

programme.title: Activate Your Japanese!
programme.desc: Drama "Xuan Tackles Japan!" After passing out, Xuan finds herself waking up in a hotel room. Ota feels responsible for Xuan's blackout and tells her that she no longer needs to be a part of the planning team for the hotel's autumn campaign. But Xuan actually wants to plan for the campaign. What should she do? "Onomatopoeia" -Share Feelings- Dondon "Welcome to My Japan!" focuses on the life of Silvia DE SOUZA from Brazil, who works at a factory that coats metal parts in Toyama Prefecture!

programme.title: Culture Crossroads
programme.sub-title: Gearing up for the Japanese Dream
programme.desc: More and more foreign students come to Japan to become certified auto mechanics and find long-term employment. We follow one such student, a young woman from Myanmar who pursues her Japanese dream.

programme.title: HELLO! NHK WORLD-JAPAN
programme.desc: Cycle Around Japan has teamed up with Taiwan's public broadcaster, PTS, for a three-part series airing this fall. Experience Taiwan's lush scenery, and meet guardians of traditional culture.

programme.title: Seasoning the Seasons
programme.desc: Kisoji is an old road that runs through Kiso in Nagano Prefecture, which is located along the Nakasendo, one of the main highroads connecting Tokyo and Kyoto Prefecture. Stretching 80 kilometers from north to south, the Kisoji is home to 11 "post towns" along its trail. The road has been used for about 400 years, with feudal lords from all over Japan using it to get to Tokyo to serve the shogun during the Samurai period. In this episode, we tour the post towns and see the deep facets of the Kisoji route.

programme.title: Seasoning the Seasons
programme.desc: Kisoji is an old road that runs through Kiso in Nagano Prefecture, which is located along the Nakasendo, one of the main highroads connecting Tokyo and Kyoto Prefecture. Stretching 80 kilometers from north to south, the Kisoji is home to 11 "post towns" along its trail. The road has been used for about 400 years, with feudal lords from all over Japan using it to get to Tokyo to serve the shogun during the Samurai period. In this episode, we tour the post towns and see the deep facets of the Kisoji route.
